original_data.question: A 47-year-old executive schedules an appointment his physician for a routine medical check-up. He currently has no complaints and claims to be “as fit as a fiddle.” The physical examination findings are unremarkable, except for a mid-systolic murmur heard in the 2nd left intercostal space that radiates to the carotids on auscultation. The physician instructs the patient to stand from a supine position with the stethoscope still placed on his chest. Which of the following changes would occur with this maneuver?

options.A: An increase in right atrial pressure
options.B: An increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
options.C: A reduction in the slope of the pacemaker potential
options.D: A reduction in diastolic filling time

model_response:
The answer is C: A reduction in the slope of the pacemaker potential. When a person stands up from a supine position, blood pools in the lower extremities. This causes a decrease in venous return to the heart, which results in a decrease in end-diastolic volume. The decrease in end-diastolic volume decreases the slope of the pacemaker potential.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A meeting arranged with someone at a particular time and place.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Period of contraction of the HEART, especially of the HEART VENTRICLES.
Space of compartment of trunk bounded by the upper and lower surfaces of two consecutive ribs.
Either of the two principal arteries on both sides of the neck that supply blood to the head and neck; each divides into two branches, the internal carotid artery and the external carotid artery.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The posture of an individual lying face up.
A reference to the alignment of an object, a particular situation or view of a situation, or the location of an object.
Instruments intended to detect and study sound produced by the heart, lungs, or other parts of the body. (from UMDNS, 1999)
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

The Phalen maneuver is performed by having the patient hold both wrists in complete and forced flexion (pushing the dorsal surfaces of both hands together) for 30-60 seconds. This can increase the pressure in the carpal tunnel. The test is positive (abnormal) if the patient experiences characteristic symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome (pain and paresthesias along the distribution of the median nerve, i.e., thumb, index finger, and middle finger). [PMID:31773104]
